body:
This looks promising, thanks for submitting!  I'm sure there are lots of people that would like to use HID cards with Kegbot/Kegboard.

Can you recommend a reader device / setup for using this?

Here are most of the changes you requested.  Note the following:
  The reader code has been ripped out and replaced. Further testing showed the original code was buggy and would get out-of-sync if there was line noise. The new code fixes that.
  It's been a long time since I did C++ with any regularity.  The variables are defined as static because that's how I could get it to compile. Since static defines that they can only be changed inside of that class / function, and it's all private anyway, I didn't figure it was too much of a problem. Please educate me why I'm wrong
  I'm not crazy about moving the pin definitions into kegboard_config alone, primarily because folks may need to take this module out and test w/ their own cards & it de-modularlizes the code a bit, preferring simplicity in configuration. To resolve this, I added more documentation in the file headers.

As for a recommended reader, any weigand-compatible tag reader should work. I'm using a HID ProxPro 5355 reader (125kHz) with 26 bit and 37 bit cards.

Thanks for making the changes.  Still needs a little work.

> The variables are defined as static because that's how I could get it to compile.
> Since static defines that they can only be changed inside of that class / function,
> and it's all private anyway, I didn't figure it was too much of a problem. Please
> educate me why I'm wrong.

It's a misuse of static and will cause problems if more than one Wiegand_Reader object is instantiated.  Marking a member variable as static tells the compiler that there shall only be one copy of the variable for the entire program -- like making it a global variable. 

> I'm not crazy about moving the pin definitions into kegboard_config alone,
> primarily because folks may need to take this module out and test w/ their
> own cards & it de-modularlizes the code a bit, preferring simplicity in configuration.

IO pins are a scarce resource, and sometimes features can conflict in their requirements, therefore the convention is to keep all pin definitions in one place.

If you're worried about introducing a dependency on kegboard_config.h, I suppose you could handle that locally:

```
#ifndef KB_INTERRUPT_BIT0
#define KB_INTERRUPT_BIT0  2  // default
#endif
...
```

Though I wouldn't bother; kegboard_config is just c-preprocessor definitions and is included by most source files.

On another note, what's the difference between `KB_INT_WEIGAND_BIT0{0,1}` and the corresponding `KB_PIN_WEIGAND_BIT{0,1}`?  I thought this protocol only required two lines, so I'm missing why four pins are used.

> As for a recommended reader, any weigand-compatible tag reader should work.
> I'm using a HID ProxPro 5355 reader (125kHz) with 26 bit and 37 bit cards.

Great, thanks -- I'll try to find a cheap one on eBay so I can play with this..

thanks,
mike

I received my own reader and wrote my own support library, submitted in 83234df01896e6a69ab8bd906c7bc3ba45ad3a59.  Give it a try?

Thanks for the suggestion.
thanks!
Thanks for the head's up -- there was a broken server-side redirect for `/kegboard` which has now been fixed.
coolio…thx for the fix.

There are a few problems here.  The biggest is that it's not integrated with kegboard in anyway. Basically the change doesn't do anything, other than chuck extra files into the repository.

Less severe: the formatting is a mess, and the commit message doesn't specify the origin and license.

Mike, your such a nightowl, I'll try and catch up with you in a few.

cheers
-Chris

Looks good, thanks!
See issue #9 -- I think we now have the support you're after.

Looks neat.

Occurs to me that we probably need a new part of the docs to describe all the optional things that can be flipped on, like this, wiegand RFID, etc..  Opened separate issue #11.
Mike - did you ever see this?

In `kegboard_config.h`, can you try disabling the buzzer?

``` cpp
#define KB_ENABLE_BUZZER 0
```

(Should fix this properly w/ issue #3).

After applying only that change, does the firmware work (LEDs turn off & board is responsive)?

Thanks for quick response.

Did that, then open .ino and compile same error - weird as I see the logic should exclude all the buzzer functions.
Whoops. `git pull` and try again; I think buzzer.c was still getting pulled in.

Fantastic, looking good now!

Loving this project - thank you so much. Will confirm once I can 100% functionally on Leo.
Awesome! Thanks, please confirm & I'll close this out.
Confirmed that version with Buzzer changed to Tone resolves this issue. Thanks!

https://spreadsheets.google.com/a/liquidintellect.com/spreadsheet/pub?key=0AtfNMvfWhA_ccnRId19SNmVWTDE0MEtTOV9HOEdQa0E&gid=0

Looks like it's pin out differences.

It looks like this is a subtle incompatibility with Mega: the logical pins (D0, D1, ...) still map to the same physical location, but they in some cases map to pins on the mcu with different capabilities.

ID12 RFID requires Software Serial support, which only works with PCINT capable pins.  Unfortunately the pin we use (D6) does not support PCINT on the mega.

Here's something you can try: These pins support PCINT on Mega:

```
10, 11, 12, 13,  50, 51, 52, 53,  62, 63, 64, 65, 66, 67, 68, 69
```

Pick one and change `KB_PIN_SERIAL_RFID_RX` in `kegboard_config.h` accordingly.  (We already use 10-13 so pick one of the others.)

Recompile and reflash.  Using a jumper wire, connect pin D6 on the Kegboard shield to the pin you selected. Then give it a try.
I'll give that a try a report back.
So jumping pin 6 to pin 53 (only picked it for it's physical accessiblity), and RFID works on my mega now.

@hanzov69 Thanks for the report. When it "hangs", you're saying one of the TX/RX LEDs stays on?  Does the CHIP led (bottom left) stop pulsing?

We saw a behavior like once this during testing, with what we later suspected to be a bad USB micro cable.  Does it happen frequently enough that you'd be able to tell if a different cable ameliorated the issue?

Sorry about that.  This was a kegbot-android bug, resolved earlier today by 11932bb98f7d481c0a965cce995fb2c02c41d908.

To work around the issue, either:
- Set a board serial number from your workstation (with `set-kegboard-serialnumber` command line program), or
- Update to [kegbot-android 1.0.0-b69](https://github.com/Kegbot/kegbot-android/releases/tag/v1.0.0-b69).
My KBPM will hang, but I'm almost certain that it's ambient temperature related.  Mine is out in a garage, and on 95+ degree days, it will kill the KBPM.  It recovers with a power cycle.

I recently updated my Arduino IDE and ran into the same problem. After some trial and error I found a workaround:

Tools -> Board -> Boards Manager
Click Arduino AVR Boards
Select version 1.6.11 or less
Click Install

Sorry to ping an old thread (I'm a bit late on the KegBot bandwagon), but maybe someone here can help resolve a similar issue?  Days of toiling have gone nowhere. 

Issue: Wiegand RFID does not work on Arduino Mega.

Setup: I'm using an Arduino Mega 2560 with a Wiegand RFID reader setup per the [wiki post](https://github.com/Kegbot/kegboard/wiki/HID-Wiegand-RFID-Reader-Support).  Connecting the reader to pin A4/A5 works fine with Arduino UNO, but fails for Mega. 

If I enable Wiegand `#define KB_ENABLE_WIEGAND_RFID 1` (and disable ID-12), then the default PIN settings `#define KB_PIN_WIEGAND_RFID_DATA0 A4
  #define KB_PIN_WIEGAND_RFID_DATA1 A5` cause _everything_ to fail (flow meters and RFID do not work) [kegboard_config reference](https://github.com/Kegbot/kegboard/blob/39c1f45470d8e4c67829cc08c9d684751725081f/arduino/kegboard/kegboard_config.h#L111). 

If I reassign the PINs for RFID to anything else (e.g. 20-21, 51,53), then flow meters work but RFID still fails.  It seems that pins 2,3,18,19,20,21 are preferred by others for Wiegand RFID [example](https://github.com/ugge75/Wiegand-Protocol-Library-for-Arduino-MEGA-2560).

Based on [the chart](https://github.com/NicoHood/PinChangeInterrupt/#pinchangeinterrupt-table) (below), the Mega pinout is quite different than the Uno and I'm at a loss to figure out why things are not compatible, or whether they even _can_ be compatible.

Is there some pin assignment where Wiegand RFID will work on the Mega?  I know that 6 taps are enabled by default for the Mega (pins 2,3,18,19,20,21) -- if two are disabled can those pins be dedicated to RFID?  When I attempt this (I tried this, and all the pins listed above by @mik3y), it does not work.

Any help is appreciated. Thanks for making Kegbot -- it's seriously awesome.  

#### Official Arduinos
```
| PCINT |  Uno/Nano/Mini  |   Mega/2560    | Leonardo/Micro | HL2 (8/16/32u2) |
| ----- | --------------- | -------------- | -------------- | --------------- |
|     0 |  8       (PB0)  | 53 SS   (PB0)  |    SS   (PB0)* |  0 SS   (PB0)*  |
|     1 |  9       (PB1)  | 52 SCK  (PB1)  |    SCK  (PB1)  |  1 SCK  (PB1)   |
|     2 | 10 SS    (PB2)  | 51 MOSI (PB2)  |    MOSI (PB2)  |  2 MOSI (PB2)   |
|     3 | 11 MISO  (PB3)  | 50 MISO (PB3)  |    MISO (PB3)  |  3 MISO (PB3)   |
|     4 | 12 MOSI  (PB4)  | 10      (PB4)  |  8/A8   (PB4)  |  4      (PB4)   |
|     5 | 13 SCK   (PB5)  | 11      (PB5)  |  9/A9   (PB5)  |  5      (PB5)   |
|     6 |    XTAL1 (PB6)* | 12      (PB6)  | 10/A10  (PB6)  |  6      (PB6)   |
|     7 |    XTAL2 (PB7)* | 13      (PB7)  | 11      (PB7)  |  7      (PB7)   |
| ----- | --------------- | -------------- | -------------- | --------------- |
|     8 | A0       (PC0)  |  0 RX   (PE0)* |                |         (PC6)*  |
|     9 | A1       (PC1)  | 15 RX3  (PJ0)* |                |         (PC5)*  |
|    10 | A2       (PC2)  | 14 TX3  (PJ1)* |                |         (PC4)*  |
|    11 | A3       (PC3)  |    NC   (PJ2)* |                |         (PC2)*  |
|    12 | A4 SDA   (PC4)  |    NC   (PJ3)* |                |         (PD5)*  |
|    13 | A5 SDC   (PC5)  |    NC   (PJ4)* |                |                 |
|    14 |    RST   (PC6)* |    NC   (PJ5)* |                |                 |
|    15 |                 |    NC   (PJ6)* |                |                 |
| ----- | --------------- | -------------- | -------------- | --------------- |
|    16 |  0 RX    (PD0)  | A8      (PK0)  |                |                 |
|    17 |  1 TX    (PD1)  | A9      (PK1)  |                |                 |
|    18 |  2 INT0  (PD2)  | A10     (PK2)  |                |                 |
|    19 |  3 INT1  (PD3)  | A11     (PK3)  |                |                 |
|    20 |  4       (PD4)  | A12     (PK4)  |                |                 |
|    21 |  5       (PD5)  | A13     (PK5)  |                |                 |
|    22 |  6       (PD6)  | A14     (PK6)  |                |                 |
|    23 |  7       (PD7)  | A15     (PK7)  |                |                 |
| ----- | --------------- | -------------- | -------------- | --------------- |
```

Its been awhile since I played with wiegand and the interrupts. But if I recall correctly, the megas have 6 hardware interrupts (2,3,18,19,20,21), and the others only have 2 (2,3), the default code uses these for the flow meters. The wiegand interface is using the PcInt ability to get additional interrupts on any other pins. One important thing to note here is that the `attachInterrupt(n, fnc, mode)` function handles the mapping of `n` to a pin, this value will always be `0-5` on a mega, which translates to pins `2,3,18,19,20,21`. When using `PCattachInterrupt(pin, fnc, mode)`, `pin` is a reference to an actual pin. From what I can tell the PCInterrupt functionality was written for the Atmega168, so I wouldn't be surprised if it has bugs related to the mega. Based on your chart above you might want to try using pins `A8-A15`

If you don't plan on using all the flow meters on the mega you can certainly repurpose their regular hardware interrupts for wiegand. In that case simply make the following changes.
 
```cpp
#if defined(__AVR_ATmega1280__) || defined(__AVR_ATmega2560__)
#define KB_NUM_METERS             6
#define KB_PIN_METER_C            21
#define KB_PIN_METER_D            20
#define KB_PIN_METER_E            19
#define KB_PIN_METER_F            18
#else
```

```cpp
PCattachInterrupt(KB_PIN_WIEGAND_RFID_DATA0, wiegandData0, FALLING);
PCattachInterrupt(KB_PIN_WIEGAND_RFID_DATA1, wiegandData1, FALLING);
```

to

```cpp
#if defined(__AVR_ATmega1280__) || defined(__AVR_ATmega2560__)
#define KB_NUM_METERS             4
#define KB_PIN_METER_C            21
#define KB_PIN_METER_D            20
#else
```

```cpp
attachInterrupt(4, wiegandData0, FALLING);
attachInterrupt(5, wiegandData1, FALLING);
```
